hotspots.label: Frost on Grass
hotspots.fact: When temperatures drop below freezing, water vapor in the air turns into tiny ice crystals that cover plants and grass. This process is called **frost** — that's when water freezes directly into ice without becoming liquid water first. Frost helps us see how weather changes affect living things in nature!

vocabulary.definition: Tiny crystals of ice that form on surfaces when the air temperature drops below freezing.

hotspots.label: Grass Structure
hotspots.fact: Grass is a plant that has adapted to survive in cold winters by storing energy in its roots underground. Even when frost covers the grass blades, the roots stay protected beneath the soil and help the plant grow again in spring. Plants have special parts that help them live in different environments!

vocabulary.definition: The parts of a plant that grow underground and absorb water and nutrients from the soil.

hotspots.label: Water Freezing
hotspots.fact: The moisture on these grass blades froze because the air temperature dropped below 32°F (0°C). When water freezes into ice crystals, it changes from a liquid to a solid — this is an example of how water can change states. This happens during fall and winter weather cycles in many places on Earth!

vocabulary.definition: The process when a liquid turns into a solid because the temperature gets cold enough.

hotspots.label: Morning Dew and Frost
hotspots.fact: You can see sparkling ice crystals on the grass because water from the air condensed and froze overnight. This teaches us about the water cycle — water moves between the air, land, and living things in nature. Cool temperatures at night cause water vapor to condense and freeze into the frost we see here!

vocabulary.definition: When water vapor in the air turns into liquid water droplets, usually when air cools down.
